moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4 d6: The opening is instead a King's Gambit Declined.
moves.3. Bc4: Chess tactics were primitive in 1575, but attacking KB7 has been part of the game since it was given its modern form.
moves.3... c6: I guess da Cutri wanted another open diagonal for his Queen. I can think of no other explanation for this move.
moves.4. Nf3: Ruy Lopez is planning a sacrificial attack on KB7.
moves.4... Bg4: Da Cutri tries to defend with a pin, immobilizing the Knight.
moves.5. fxe5: Ruy Lopez has seen one move farther.
moves.6. Bxf7+: Now this move wins two Pawns.
moves.7. Nxe5+: This fork wins the exposed Bishop.
moves.7... Ke8: As good or bad as anything else.
moves.8. Qxg4: Not only does Ruy Lopez win back the piece, he also augments his attack on da Cutri's undeveloped position by mobilizing the Queen.
moves.8... Nf6: He has to do somethig to slow the onslaught.
moves.9... Qe7: Trying to break the attack, although even if Ruy Lopez exchanges Queens his two Pawns up give him a technically easy win [by modern standards].
moves.10... Qd8: He has no choice, but now disaster strikes.
moves.12. Nf7+: The Rook falls. Da Cutri resigned the game. Ruy Lopez went on to win the match and become the unofficial "champion".

players: Ruy Lopez de Segura  vs. Giovanni Leonardo di Bona da Cutri
